definitions.definition: used in polite offers or invitations

examples.text: **Would you like** a sandwich?
Would you have dinner with me on Friday?

definitions.definition: used to say what you like, love, hate, etc.
definitions.sensetop: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc. somethingwould like, etc. to do somethingwould like, etc. somebody to do somethingwould rather do somethingwould rather somebody did something

examples.text: I'd love a coffee.
examples.contextForm: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc. something

examples.text: I'd be only too glad to help.
examples.contextForm: would like, etc. to do something

examples.text: I'd hate you to think I was criticizing you.
examples.contextForm: would like, etc. somebody to do something

examples.text: I'd rather come with you.
I'd rather you came with us.

definitions.definition: used as the past form of will when reporting what somebody has said or thought

examples.text: He said he would be here at eight o'clock *(= His words were: ‘I will be there at eight o'clock.’)*.
She asked if I would help.
They told me that they probably wouldn't come.

definitions.definition: used for talking about the result of an event that you imagine

examples.text: She'd look better with shorter hair.
If you went to see him, he would be delighted.
Hurry up! It would be a shame to miss the beginning of the play.
She'd be a fool to accept it *(= if she accepted)*.

definitions.definition: used for describing a possible action or event that did not in fact happen, because something else did not happen first

examples.text: If I had seen the advertisement in time, I would have applied for the job.
They would never have met if she hadn't gone to Emma's party.

definitions.definition: used for saying why somebody does something
definitions.sensetop: so that somebody/something would do somethingin order that somebody/something would do something

examples.text: She burned the letters so that her husband would never read them.
examples.contextForm: so that somebody/something would do something

examples.text: He worked hard in order that he would pass all his exams.
examples.contextForm: in order that somebody/something would do something

definitions.definition: used for saying what you want to happen

examples.text: I wish that you'd be quiet for a minute.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody/something was not willing or refused to do something

examples.text: She wouldn't change it, even though she knew it was wrong.
My car wouldn't start this morning.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.text: **Would you mind** leaving us alone for a few minutes?
Would you open the door for me, please?

definitions.definition: used to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.text: I would imagine the job will take about two days.
I'd say he was about fifty.
**I wouldn't** have any more to drink, **if I were you**.

definitions.definition: used for talking about things that often happened in the past

examples.text: When my parents were away, my grandmother would take care of me.
He'd always be the first to offer to help.

definitions.definition: used for talking about behaviour that you think is typical

examples.text: ‘She said it was your fault.’ ‘Well, **she would say that**, **wouldn't she?** She's never liked me.’

definitions.definition: used to express a strong wish

examples.text: Would that he had lived to see it.

wordOrigin: Old English wolde, past of wyllan, of Germanic origin.
